snippet: Even after the Supreme Court narrowed its scope, prosecutors are still using the “honest services” measure to go after lawmakers they say have accepted bribes.
abstract: Broad charges announced this week against Democratic State Senator Malcolm A Smith of Queens and five other political figures shows that prosecutors are still using honest-services fraud charges to go after lawmakers they say have accepted bribes; charges come more than a year after Supreme Court ruling that narrowed the scope of law, limiting it to bribes and kickbacks rather than undisclosed conflicts of interest.
lead_paragraph: Even after the Supreme Court narrowed its scope, prosecutors are still using the “honest services” measure to go after lawmakers they say have accepted bribes.

headline.seo: Scandal Suggests Anti-Corruption Law Survived Encounter With Supreme Court
headline.main: Scandal Suggests Narrower Corruption Law Still Survived
headline.print_headline: Scandal Suggests Narrower Corruption Law Still Survived
